title: Days, Months, and Telling Time
description: Learn how to express days of the week, months of the year, and tell time in Portuguese.
objectives: Name all days of the week
Say the months of the year

vocabulary.notes: Used for half past the hour

grammar.title: Days of the Week Pattern
grammar.content: Portuguese days (except Saturday and Sunday) follow a numbering pattern from segunda (second) to sexta (sixth) feira. This comes from religious tradition counting from Sunday.

grammar.title: Telling Time - Singular vs Plural
grammar.content: Use 'É' for one o'clock, 'São' for all other hours. Add 'e' for minutes past the hour, 'menos' for minutes before the hour.
examples: São sete menos dez. (It's 6:50 / ten to seven)

grammar.title: Using 'Em' with Days
grammar.content: Use 'em' or contracted forms for 'on' a specific day. Masculine days use 'no', feminine use 'na'.

exercises.question: How do you say 'It's 3:30' in Portuguese?
exercises.explanation: 'São três e meia' means 'It's 3:30'. 'Meia' means half.

exercises.question: What does 'hoje' mean?
exercises.explanation: 'Hoje' means 'today'. It's one of the most common time words.

exercises.question: Complete: ____ é segunda-feira. (Today is Monday)
exercises.explanation: 'Hoje' means today. 'Hoje é segunda-feira' = 'Today is Monday'.

exercises.question: Which is the correct way to say 'It's 1:00'?
exercises.explanation: For 1 o'clock, use the singular 'É uma hora'. For other hours, use 'São'.

culturalNotes.title: Work Week in Portugal
culturalNotes.content: The typical Portuguese work week is Monday to Friday. Shops and businesses may close for lunch (1-3pm). Many smaller shops close on Sunday, though tourist areas and shopping centers stay open.

culturalNotes.title: Punctuality
culturalNotes.content: While Portuguese culture is generally relaxed, being on time for business meetings is important. Social gatherings may have more flexible timing. If invited to dinner at 8pm, arriving 15-20 minutes late is acceptable.

culturalNotes.title: 24-Hour Clock
culturalNotes.content: Portugal uses the 24-hour clock in official contexts (train times, TV schedules). In conversation, people use the 12-hour format. Context makes it clear if it's morning or afternoon.
